comments.commentBody:
What other industry breeds such fanatically loyal customers, so loyal their entire world revolves around your products?

The gun industry is a marvel.

Imagine if Seattle were to become swept by theories that the government was planning to send in the 101st Airborne to remove all coffee products, and locals were feverishly buying up as many bags of beans and Krups machines as they could find, and burying them out in their back yards for safety.

How's your beans?

My beans are dry, friend, my beans are dry.
Just okay, we used fresh corn, and it came out a bit too sweet.  Increase the amount of green onions, and add some bacon and bacon fat in place of the butter.
Cities are police empires? And what does this have to do with military exercises?
How about the rest of the country is concerned for the safety of our families if these lunatics spill over Texas borders and rampage elsewhere

@katieatl: unfortunately, these are traits that have become quite common in Liberals, strangely enough. I espouse many Liberal views separately; but I can't stand the self-righteousness and entitlement of the "totalitarian Liberals", who seem to miss Stalin.

Where in Bart S.' comment does he speak of people "threatening US military personnel with weapons"?  He specifically states that "people who are worried about this exercise should be barred from owning firearms."  A "worry" is not a threat.  My comment addressed the actual words in Bart's comment.  Yours, SS, did not.
The people who are worried about this exercise should be barred from owning firearms. If they resist, they should be locked up.

Yes that is all fine...except for the part where you compared the Nazi takeover of France with a military training exercise that has happened for many years int he southwest of the US.

Oh yea-nice touch in putting Obama and Hitler in the same camp. thank goodness the paranoid people of Texas are preventing Obama from doing just what Hitler did.

and Elke
Does this Lieber have any connection to the Lieber of chocolates, e.g. Chanukah gelt and also pesach goodies ?

I find the Supreme Court's recent interpretation of the 2nd Amendment to be contributing to the paranoia in the "Heartland."  In my view, the possession of arms were, in the 18th Century colonies, important to the State militias, which were a major part of the country's army.  This is no longer the case.  The notion that a bunch of middle aged men armed with M16s can be a match for the US Military.

I hope that you are right. I worry about the 20% who watch Fox.
This is all done to wip up the electorate against Pro Choice Dems,
notably Hillary. We need help from the Press & many people to support the absolute right to an abortion. My daughters have it &
I want my granddaughters to have that right also.

We do seem to have an affinity for scandals, especially in America having grown up with a few taking place over my head. If I remember correctly it was Bill Clinton who acquired a tarnished image and we couldn't get enough of it, with our eyes glued to the newspapers. 'O the shame of it all, how despicable', we exclaimed. There goes national security, look at the President and what he has done to his poor wife and the Country.

Give this American a break with the tabloid reporting and hatred, the mob howling for blood. Mrs. Clinton is the only politician running for Presidency who has validity for this voter's support, and makes one feel at ease in the face of this muddle of marathon runners running off in all directions, while she remains cool and contained.

It is possible she may be facing Walker in the political arena soon, and she has my endorsement because she is far more recognizable to my mind than any of these political anomalies walking among our midst at a pivotal time in American history where the Future of our Country and its vision is more important than ever.

morGan:

Yes, her image is badly tarnished, but she also has another image. It's the storybook one of a strong, smart and incredibly competent woman rising up in a man's world, etc., etc. The problem is that image gets seriously tested every time she has to deviate from her script.

Keeping her under wraps to protect that image seems to be the current strategy.

Scandals like Whitewater DO indeed abound.

Do you know hat Whitewater WAS? You may be aware that some tote-the-note used car dealers take your down payment and as soon as you are so many days late on a payment, they repo your car and sell it to the next victim.

THAT was what I understand the Clintons were doing with Whitewater houses. As soon as people were the bare minimum time late on their house notes, the houses were seized only to be re-sold a few weeks later.

She is smart but, it turns out, not all that impressive. Kind of mundane, really. The more you get to know her, the less there seems to be to get to know.

Turns out, the most exciting thing about Hillary is her image.
Fetal tissues are indeed very valuable for studying human development through stem cells. Anybody can google for it and learn about it.
Nope, Chapter 11. 10 was the rabid attacks on Palin. You do count that one as well, don't you?
Republicans are writing Chapter 10 of the War on Women

Maybe you could implore the Christians to start behaving even slightly more like the historical Christ and then they would gain our respect again?  Until then, in the public sphere christians have chosen the political position of misogynic racists, which has nothing to do with their historical mission.  I would recommend Pope Francis as a role model instead of Jerry Falwell.

@Matt, unfortunately, the anti-abortion "hate and fear mongers" have strongly infused their campaign with Christianity. I agree that it is odious how this strain of the far-right distorts Christianity, but they do. And so it is up to you and your like-minded counterparts to wrest the religion and its reputation away from them.

Amen, brother! The majority of Christian are not right wing crazies and we have nothing but love and empathy for our sisters who have made the tough decision to abort a pregnancy. Research and science are gifts to us all but can be especially meaningful to a woman in this situation- a hope to create something beautiful, something to help others- out of something so difficult.

Iran deal, fracking, drought, climate change, Putin invading Ukraine, genocide in Sudan and GOP leaders steer our tax dollars to focus on this? It's obvious they are pandering to a right-leaning Christian base for votes. We need Planned Parenthood. It empowers choice and responsibility--something these GOP leaders need to start upholding.

Hurricane Katrina was pretty bad and the feds committed plenty of sins -- but mostly by failing to do things they should have done -- like providing emergency food, shelter and housing -- not a whole lot of assaulting people -- especially the elderly -- at least that I heard of and I hang out in that area quite a bit and had property that was severely damaged.

This they don't do, nor do they put their money where their mouth is when it comes to the birth of defective babies whose births could be prevented by advanced testing.
A perfect case in point is Bella Santorum, who has a rare genetic condition that will prevent her from living a normal life, either in abilities or in length. But because her father was formerly a U.S. senator, and now a presidential candidate, the taxpayers foot the bills for her. If she were born to ordinary mortals, let alone someone poor of of color, this would not happen--"You're on your own."
Rick Santorum and his ilk would make birth control either illegal or unaffordable, outlaw abortion in all cases, and force the issue of births of children whose early medical care would mount in the hundreds of thousands if not millions of dollars and still would not have a normal life--and they would prevent their proper, affordable care through the ACA. (And they call themselves pro-life?)
I think that's great because you shouldn't be in health care- the sooner you're gone the better.

And if that's what your conscience tells you to do, that's fine.  I just hope, if you're in the position to be recommending treatment choices, that you don't make that choice for patients by editing the options you present to them.

Pathetic posturing by conservatives. With the woman's permission, fetal organs are made available to medical researchers. Shockingly enough, tissue storage and transportation costs money.

I have an idea, let all conservatives opposed to this practice sign a formal contract that they will never receive any medical treatment with any link to fetal tissue research. Time for them to put their lives on the line.
Do you mean to tell me that the GOP wasn't -already- investigating Planned Parenthood? I find that hard to believe.

This stuff is very easily made into the grotesque.

For people who don't understand scientific research techniques, the stuff simply makes them want to throw up. And for those who religiously believe that abortion is equal to murder, nausea automatically becomes outrage.

This is really low hanging fruit for the extreme right wing fringe.

For the scientific community, those of us who appreciate the benefits of scientific research, and for those who might directly benefit from medical research, it is a crying shame.

Paul:

Invoking Trump? Beats Rush Limbaugh. It's now only a matter of time before we start hearing that Trump is the "de facto head" of the Republican Party.

"How can...that not make someone at least question their pro-abortion stand?"

I'll tell you how: by reigning in religiously-programmed emotion and reaction and engaging brain to consider the larger picture with critical reasoning, nuanced understanding, and SCIENCE. Those hearts, lungs, livers are part of a system and growth process NOT YET COMPLETE AND INDEPENDENTLY FUNCTIONING AS A WHOLE. Until then, the life and rights of the already-born woman carrying that POTENTIAL are supreme, period.

And really, with all the humans overrunning the planet and children born in poverty and abuse to women who possibly didn't even want to be mothers, life at that stage is just not that "precious" and certainly not "sanctified" as some commenters claim. I made that choice during a difficult time with a man long gone and I along with that collection of not-yet sentient parts are so much better for it. Instead, I shower my love and creative energy on my family members and community. Just because you chose to be a "mom" doesn't give you, the other commenters here, and the religious minority of this country the right to force views and choices on me with insinuating and, frankly, insulting comments.

With a complex universe surrounding us with life, seemingly infinite diversity, and yes, death, how can that not make you at least question your anti-choice stand?

Actually, it does make perfect sense. Let me spell it out simply for you: one is born, sentient, and living independent of its maternal parent; the other is not and not even capable of it until viability. Do you really not see that critical difference?
Apparently, you haven't spent any time around physicians and how they converse about medical procedures.

Nucatola explains, “We’ve been very good at getting heart, lung, liver, because we know that, so I’m not gonna crush that part, I’m gonna basically crush below, I’m gonna crush above, and I’m gonna see if I can get it all intact.”
How can hearing, or reading that not make someone at least question their pro-abortion stand? Hearts, lungs and livers are not in any way parts of a woman's reproductive system. They belong to someone else.
If Planned Parenthood becomes a thing of the past, I wonder what other issue Republicans will dream up that would have the same emotional cachet.
I understand Planned Parenthood has been purchasing centrifuges. I predict in a matter days, perhaps hours, the WMDs will turn up beside the Clorox in that old plastic pail under the sink.
For the first time in my life I am grateful to Texas for something -- a good laugh.  This kind of lunacy can not be made up.
I was sure that we were living in the 21st century. This nation has more than one flag on the Moon but, after reading this article, I was haunted by a doubt.
Uh, Michael, this is not the same president that lied to us about a war in Iraq.

I have another home in Emerald Isle NC about 15 miles from Camp Lejeune. Daily we listen to the tank cannons fire and are pretty used to it. What we never get used to is the howitzers. We have to secure the kitchen cabinets and dishes  because the vibrations are so severe.

Years ago when I lived on the north shore of Oahu, there were serious military training 'games' once a month, usually during the full moon. Many tanks and trucks full of soldiers in camo paint drove up to these mountainside grounds, right on the Kamehameha Hwy. in huge convoys. You could hear the sounds in the far distance of weaponry fire for hours. At first I found it unsettling but since it was done so often you actually got used to it somehow. I'm sure it happens in other places like perhaps Alaska. These practices did not seem to disturb anyone much. Matter of fact nobody ever really mentioned or talked about it at all. It was just an accepted part of life in this area. Lots of military activity in and around the Hawaiian Islands. No locals freaked out nor do I remember any of these activities given a code name. The public was not even given any prior notice. They just showed up and did their jobs. Oddly it gave me a sense of security knowing they were prepared if ever needed to respond locally to a real event.

The hysteria over this exercise is hilarious. It's also a little bit unsettling, because it makes one wonder how firm a grasp on reality some of these people have and how close they might be to tripping offline and doing something crazy.

Some will argue that this training is not necessary, or could be done on base. Nonsense. This type of "real-world" training and the immersion it provides are absolutely essential for our SOF Operators, particularly the guys serving as the "underground." It's essential that these guys be able to learn to operate in the open, to literally "hide in plain sight" as it were, and you just can't replicate that on base to the degree of realism and immersion necessary to make this training truly effective. And if these guys can't learn to operate "under the radar" in the U.S., how can we expect them to do that in some overseas location like Iraq, Syria or Yemen when we need them to?
It's a crazy world out there, and we need Operators who can pop into foreign locations, blend in with the locals and conduct irregular warfare operations without being detected, captured or killed. These exercises give them the ability to train for that mission in a way they simply couldn't do on base.
If people don't want our forces to conduct this type of training, my suggestion would be to put down the shovel you're using to bury your guns, and go to the polls and elect officials who won't constantly embroil us in situations that make this training necessary.
